situation: Our engineering project aimed to design student housing buildings that incorporate a rooftop gathering space. The objective was to provide an optimal living and learning environment for students, while also considering sustainability and utility.
task_action: To approach this project with integrity and responsibility, we began by conducting comprehensive research on sustainable building technologies and incorporating ethical issues into our design process. We built a collaborative team, with each member contributing their experience and thoughts. Our initial step was to conduct intensive brainstorming sessions in which we considered many design choices while keeping ethical ideals like environmental impact, accessibility, and social responsibility in mind. We next carefully examined the project's location, taking into account aspects such as sunshine exposure, wind patterns, and community needs. This influenced our decision-making process and assured that our design would complement the surrounding environment and serve the neighbourhood. During the design and building stages, we prioritised ethical considerations such as using ecologically friendly materials, optimising energy efficiency, and encouraging inclusiveness in our design. We also maintained transparency and honesty in our contact with stakeholders, addressing any ethical issues or conflicts that developed during the project.
result: Due to our ethical and socially responsible approach, we were able to effectively produce a design that fulfilled our clients' needs while maintaining ethical standards. Our final layout incorporated sustainable aspects such as solar panels, rainwater collection systems, and green spaces, demonstrating our commitment to the environment. Furthermore, our design emphasised accessibility and inclusivity, including wheelchair ramps and gender-neutral amenities, ensuring that all students could readily use and enjoy the lodgings. Overall, our project demonstrated the importance of ethics, integrity, and social responsibility in engineering design and construction. We not only attained our technological objectives, but also made a positive contribution to society and the environment by incorporating ethical issues at all stages of the process.

situation: When approaching any engineering task, using data driven decision making is absolutely crucial. Collecting data in engineered structures allows engineers to have a clearer and scientifically supported understanding of their mechanism. By incorporating derived data into your decisions surrounding your product you will be able to produce a higher quality result. Through learning this during the ENGG1050 unit, the quality of our RGM machine was thus called into question when collecting data on the reliability of the machine to complete each individual function. We had many events in the function that originally had a low reliability score when tested 10 times. It was decided that we would need to have a discussion on how to improve these events and use our current data to assist our decisions.
task_action: Therefore, by utilising this method we held a team discussion on what areas of the questioned events was causing the weakness by analysing and assessing our current data. We next changed necessary variables in each event until the accuracy met the satisfaction of the entire team. This step was repeated a number of times to ensure the highest result was obtained, such as assessing whether a change in the weight of the ball, reinforcement of elements of the events or a multitude of things being incorporated simultaneously would produce the highest reliability score. When incorporating this tactic into our RGM machine my team and I were able to significantly improve our machine's accuracy and reliability, therefore increasing the overall quality of our product.
result: Through my team's shared desire to produce a high quality machine that could be reproducible due to high reliability scores we used our collection of data to effect our decisions of each individual event. This proved to be an incredibly efficient and effective tactic for our RGM. We are all very pleased with the new reliability results of our RGM with each event achieving at least 90% reliability.

situation: We needed to add space for stairs in our model, however, there were obstructions between other rooms.
task_action: As a team, we communicated and collaborated our ideas, which were to rearrange the rooms to make enough space for stairs to be added. This included remeasuring our spaces to match the area of the requirements and extending some places to fit in other areas. Each of our group members proposed a rearrangement, and together we decided which position was best.
result: We were able to fit in stairs to get to each level of our student housing accomodation together. This ensured that all of our group members were satisfised with the decision. It also allowed us stay within the requirements for the model making project.

situation: As a first year engineering student completing the ENGG1050 unit, I was placed in a group of people who I have never met, and tasked with completing a Rube Goldberg Machine project with this group.
task_action: Throughout the weeks of working together, I faced many challenges in areas such as communication and decision-making. As a first-year student joining a new group of students, I was quite nervous when introducing myself for the first time as I did not know anyone, and was unsure if someone would turn out to be unfriendly or judgemental. I would focus on finishing our given task which resulted in all of us effectively working together. However, this required a lot of initiative as I had to "break the ice" and remove the feeling of anxiety and nervousness that I had. Additionally, I also had to face many scenarios where me and my group were uncertain of what we should do. This forced me to take the initiative and provide possible solutions that we could use to finally make a decision in order to progress and move forward.
result: As a result, I was able to gain a lot of experience in dealing with situations where I feel anxious or uncertain of what to do, especially in a space where I do not know anyone. I was also able to take the initiative in many scenarios and try to make the best decision possible when facing uncertainty, effectively improving my communication, initiative, and decision-making skills.

situation: During the duration of the semester, the team and I were tasked with designing and building a Rube Goldberg Machine. The project encouraged an exemplary sense of engineering principles whilst amplifying the roles and responsibilities of student engineers. Our team came up with the marquee idea of tackling the tedious task of feeding our pets.
task_action: From the very beginning the team and I stressed the importance of a systematic approach to problem solving, this would further enhance our roles and responsibilities of what it means to be an engineer. Our brainstorming sessions were calculated and meticulously designed to get the very best out of everyone, through this stage we identified the strengths and weaknesses of each individual and progressed further. The building stage required integral engineering skills, such as the use of an Arduino and the need to apply enough tension to a string to get the desired amount of elevation. Once the machine was assembled and the functionality of the machine was tested it was incumbent on the team to analyse any problems we encountered, it was incumbent on us to find the root cause, devise and implement a solution. This not only highlighted our ability to manage resources and time efficiently, it highlighted our ability to problem solve which is essential in the role and responsibilities of an engineer.
result: The result was a fully functioning automated pet feeding system, the contraption was built through a series of trial and error which intuitively highlighted our engineering capabilities but also provided a hands-on understanding of the roles and responsibilities of engineering. The experience to create an RGM contraption that allows us to feed our pets autonomously highlighted the broad spectrum and vital role that engineering plays in our day to day lives.

situation: We needed to figure out how to present one of our presentations during class and explain briefly on the topic of Arduino and its necessities in the modern world.
task_action: Since our main focus is on the importance of oral presentations, we all gathered up in a group of 5 and noted down what are the key points we had to follow as we present. Since the topic was related to Arduino, we all made sure to have thorough research on the topic before we speak on it so that we get a better idea and learn how to present it without looking at any reference material for a long time. Then we made a rubric and strived to use it to the best of our abilities and form a consistent and valid presentation.
result: When we completed the rubric into 5 parts, each person took the initiative of working one their desired task and complete it, if they were to have doubts then we all will help as each person in the group plays a vital role in the presentation and depending on how confident we speak with clarity then we get more marks.

situation: Being presented with the large load of content to learn in the Technical Drawing workshop.
task_action: Breaking down the fundamentals of each drawing style and their requirements prior to any attempt to ensure I understood their purpose and distinctive qualities allowed me to form my own understanding of the content with every session, before having ample opportunity to practise the process itself.
result: The result was incrementally furthering my skillset with every piece completed, and feeling more capable and confident with my abilities.

situation: We needed to finish a student accomodation model for civil modelling and was way behind due to the responsibility put onto me and my partner.
task_action: Completing a student accommodation model, with a large group of 7 people the project should have been easily completed if tasks were assigned to each person and were 'fair' to each person. In my case, it was not and this was the same for my partner since we were forced upon the responsibility of building a whole student accommodation model that required 5 members to build it efficiently but was ultimately left to my partner and me unfairly and due to my partner and me being unable to finish the model for the assignment, the other group members selfishly tried to apply for special consideration through a supposed car crash that damaged our model making it seem like the other members also participated in the production of the student accommodation. Due to these unfair circumstances, my partner and I pleaded our case about the unfair workload and the truth about the lie for special consideration.
result: The result was being able to plead my and my partner's case about the whole situation to the tutor. Even if we may still be getting low to possibly 0 marks due to it being a group assignment, my partner and I came to a consensus that we'd rather all get 0 marks than have others freeload off our work due to unfairness.

situation: We were given a set of Arduino Electrical Engineering tasks to do each week and there were about 7 each week.
task_action: We worked independently and as a group to figure out the solutions using buttons, LEDs, sketches, coding, loops, wires, and everything else available in Tinkercad Arduino. Throughout this process, we had to use math, communication, teamwork, critical thinking, and numerous other skills to achieve the results necessary to pass the course. The group I was with kept in contact with each other via text and social media to ensure not only that we were getting the work done on time but we were also making the working environment more friendly for everyone as people get to know each other better.
result: Our excellent communication and teamwork skills allowed us to create a friendlier and more comfortable environment for everyone in the group. This ensured that we also enjoyed our time in the Arduino Circuit Building.

situation: I needed to brainstorm a code for playing Rock, Paper, and Scissors. With a computer.
task_action: Undergoing a brainstorming session with the instructor; viewing ideas from everybody present in the class; coming up with a draft after a lot of trial and error; testing the draft program;
result: The result was being able to come up with a code that allowed me to reach the objective set. Out of a total of 3 drafts, I decided to use the most efficient and less complicated one.

situation: We were required to make floor plans in order to make our project model.

Thereafter, we stick back to work from basics and were able to figure out something more appropriate and better.
result: As a conclusion we were able to make a great project that satisfies all requirements and also looked good and modern.

situation: I needed to complete multiple technical drawings for an assessment within a limited time frame.
task_action: Whilst going through each of the drawings that needed to be finished, I began thinking about how much time each one would require, subsequently, I ranked them in order of complexity (from least to most complex, or from least to most time necessary). This allowed me to determine which tasks would require the most time dedicated to them, and as such, approach the issue in an orderly and logical manner.
result: As a result, I was able to complete the drawings within the time frame by finishing the easier ones first. This allowed me to finish more drawings in a smaller time frame, therefore being able to spend more time on the more intricate drawings.

situation: I was apart of the Software engineering workshop and was tasked with creating a scissors paper rock game, with many different variations, and needed to figure out how to mathematically determine the winner between two players. I needed to make decisions how to to complete this task whilst being uncertain of if it was possible.
task_action: To accomplish this task I met with a friend trying to solve the same problem and we brainstormed how we could achieve it, and struggled as it was a difficult task to complete. We then also researched online and visited forums to see what other people had come up with, which was helpful in alleviated some of the uncertainty as we found promising resources that we would be able to build off. We then discussed the options we could take to try and achieve the goal, and began prototyping the different solutions to determine if they were able to complete the requirements and be achievable in the time frame.
result: The result was that were able to create a mathematical equation that could determine the winner of a scissors paper rock game with an infinite number of gestures. Our brainstorming and research had left us with 3 different approaches to the problem, which we then prototyped and had to make a decision about which would most likely achieve the results we were after.

situation: I am an international student living alone here without family. Therefore, for me, a lot of responsibilities now. To perform all work together I have to prioritization and concentration.
task_action: Until this time, I never lived without family. The education system here is different from my country. So I have to spend lots of time behind me studies. Afterward studying, I have to do work to pay my daily costs. While I was in my country I could only study nothing but here the situation is different. At the end of the day, there is no one to help and support me, and I even have to think about cooking when coming home. As a new international student, all these things create pressure . Suddenly, I understood that it was impossible to complete all these tasks simultaneously. Then, I decided to identify my top priority first. For example, if there is an exam tomorrow, then my priority will be the ability to focus on the exam . After the exam, I can move higher the line and focus on my job and cooking staff.
result: I've been in Australia for three months now. I found the first two months to be too challenging. But it doesn't seem to be as difficult as it was previously. Since I am skilled at setting priorities and concentrating on everything.

situation: The team was struggling with communication revolving around team meetings and assignment of the minute taking and writing the reflection. Due to unforeseen circumstances, the rotation of the roles had been thrown off and uncertainty remained about who was responsible for what role
task_action: Undergoing a brainstorming session; forming a small working group with the problem statement clearly articulated and using the gallery method of brainstorming we devised several viable options. Subsequently, we evaluated each of the suggested options and rank them in order of importance, based on the parameters (such as weight, complexity, and manufacturability). After intervention from our tutor and a unified team understanding of the improvements needed to be made, the team organised for two people to be given their respective roles of writing minutes and the reflection with additional time given immediately after the Monday class to address the specific topic of reflection and the quality of the minutes.
result: The result was we were granted the leniency to resubmit our previous weeks reflection and improved upon some of our previous marks. We also had a more structured understanding of who was responsible for what role leading into this week.

situation: We had a group project in high school in which we had to make a presentation and use the limited resources given to us to create a pop up project of the solar system. We had one week to complete it and were in a group of 2. However, I had been very sick/ill that week and my partner wasn’t that enthusiastic or motivated to complete or do the project, however he did say that he will design the pop-up art of the solar system. Long story short even though I was sick and didn’t attend school for that whole week I had done some of the work at home on the information of each planet and the solar system that was going to be included on the pop-up art. However, on the day of the presentation the partner I had been with had done nothing. Luckily for us we were the last to present and the teacher had given us some paper, colours and other equipment to quickly formulate our project, although we had little to 50 minutes to get it done and present it.
task_action: We had to be quick and intelligent with our decisions as we had short amount of time on our hands. We had split the task into two sections, my partner worked on the design of the pop up art and myself worked on finishing up on the information of the pop-up art. However, we realised we needed to work on the project (pop-up art) itself as without it we wouldn’t be able to present a project at all. I made a vital decision to help to make the pop-up art as it took longer than expected. The materials the teacher had given us weren’t the best but we had to make do with it. Once we finished the design of the project my partner and I quickly copied down the information I had gathered online on the pop-up art, we had around five minutes to do this, and there was a lot of information to copy down. Somehow, we had completed the entire project just under 50 minutes due to strategic planning and working hard.
result: The result was being able to complete the project under time restriction and limited resources having to strategically resource management. Even more surprisingly was how well we worked together due to this adversity, it gave us even more of a reason to complete the project and to do better and that showed in the results/feedback that were given to us a few weeks later in which our project had the second highest mark in the class.

situation: We were required to plan and construct a model of student housing on the Macquarie campus as a group, following a criteria of needs including communal gathering spaces, housing, bathrooms, laundries etc.
task_action: The task required us as a group to effectively time and resource manage multiple different assignments, including a model, a report, and a presentation. In order to do this, it was integral to properly communicate and split the workload amongst each member in order to finish all required tasks. Subsequently, we all made sure to keep in touch outside of class via messaging and collaborate in class to ensure that all members were aware of what was required of them so that everything was finished within a timely manner. This also extended to the resource management in the construction of our model, as we planned our build with limited materials.
result: The result was being able to work cohesively in a time efficient manner to complete all tasks including the report, presentation, and final model. This ultimately enabled us to manage all our resources and complete all tasks for their respective submissions.

situation: We needed to draw a series of objects with Multiview projections using the appropriate scale.
task_action: After planning out and selecting which object I would be drawing, I had to draw the object using the appropriate scale. Doing this initially, I struggled with grasping the concept of multiview projections and had to erase my work and start again as I had messed up the order of the multiview drawings. To subsequently fix this, I asked for help which I was helped with, from this advice, I was able to finish the drawings using the correct scale, dimensions and parameters.
result: The result was I was able to successfully finish the initial drawing using multiview projections and subsequently complete the next series of multiview sketches.

situation: As an Engineer, "creative thinking" is essential. The ability to think creatively and effectively communicate potential possibilities is a valuable asset in any professional setting. These are essential skills for innovation, problem-solving, and project progress. "We came together to discuss the most effective way of utilizing this tool for our ongoing RGM project."
task_action: "Thinking Creatively and Communicating Possibilities" Integrating this tool into our RGM project requires a strategic approach that encourages innovation, collaboration, and effective communication. Firstly, we ensured every team member understood the problem from multiple perspectives. Each member was tasked with gathering and effectively communicating information on current solutions, limitations, and potential risks. Each team member presented their solution, using presentation and visual aids to communicate possibilities effectively. We also included how the solution innovatively addresses the project challenges.
result: After brainstorming sessions with team members, we finally refined and narrowed down some ideas based on feasibility, impact, and relevance. The team has innovative solutions that can achieve some goals to deliver the project on time. We divide them into parts to distribute them among team members for further development.

situation: I was in one of several groups in a Maths competition in which we had to solve questions of varying difficulty for a prize consisting of a basket of sweets.
task_action: We as a group selected several questions of varying type and difficulty, and then attempted to solve them separately within two minutes. After the two minutes were up, we put together our answers and determined who was more suited to specific types and difficulties, and split up the work accordingly.
result: The result was that we were able to work with increased efficiency, with multiple questions being solved at a time by the person most capable of solving them quickly and correctly.

situation: I Needed to complete my ENGG1000 machine workshop project (a steel toolbox) by the deadline in despite of making a mistake while cutting in the second week.
task_action: When I incorrectly used the guillotine on my first cut I immediately thought I had made my steel sheet redundant as it had been cut in half, along the wrong line. I utilised my resource management skills to redraw my pieces onto the now two smaller sheets of steel I had. In doing this I was able to salvage 4 of the 5 required steel panels from my sheets and the other from the scrap bin. Throughout the rest of the project I was very affective with my time management and planned out every step I needed to complete each week to meat the deadline, in despite of my mistake at the beginning.
result: The result was I ended up finishing my toolbox a week prior to the deadline as I was able to often complete more than what I had planned in weeks prior due to a more affective use of time management.

situation: I need to be able to complete all of my technical drawings in the allocated time frame
task_action: every week, we are given 3 hours to finish each lesson. These 3 hours are very important, because we are given special tools that allow us to draw with consistent angles and lengths. Without these tools, it is almost impossible to draw up to standard, meaning I can't finish these drawings outside of class time. I prioritised which drawings would be harder to do without the special tools provided. for example, Isometric and Oblique drawings had a very high priority, since the need to be drawn at very specific angles, which I can't do with the tools I have at home. Next is the technical drawings, since everything has to be drawn perfectly vertical or horizontal. These have a lower priority because I can do touch-ups and small lines by lining up a small triangle ruler with my page at home. Finally, the lowest priority drawings are perspective drawings. Vertical and horizontal lines can be done as mentioned before, and are much rarer. All of the other lines require no tools except for a basic ruler making them less risky to do at home. After I prioritise my drawings for the day, I allocate no more than 1.5 hours per drawing. If any take longer than that, I'll skip them and try finishing them at home.
result: A total of 19 technical drawings completed and submitted before the due date.

situation: I wanted to design, manufacture and program a macropad for my personal computer.
task_action: Over the course of the project I needed to find solutions to design bottlenecks, manufacturing requirements and design simplification. I came up with new ways to layout components for optimised space efficiency while maximising usability. I created unique solutions to casing mechanisms such that no screws were required in the assembly and found ways to implement 3D printing for every non-electronic component.
result: By the end of the project I had completed a working macropad which could be reprogrammed to perform functions on keypress, and created many innovative solutions to improve efficiency, ergonomics and aesthetics in designing.

situation: I needed to learn how to draw in multiple different views and angles so as to achieve an efficient understanding of the object for planning and blueprinting. I also need to accurately draw in the correct scales.
task_action: By listening to my tutors and watching the explanatory videos on iLearn I gained comprehensive knowledge on how to draw in isometric and oblique view and to scale the drawing correctly. Subsequently, Multi-view drawing and dimensioning was also further touched upon to increase the accuracy of my drawing of the objects.
result: The result was being able to draw correct scaling and in multiple views as well as being able to accurately write in dimensions.

situation: I needed to complete Arduino tasks that I was unfamiliar with and did not know how to complete.
task_action: Whilst going through the incomplete tasks, I decided to make a list of things I needed to ask my tutor about to effectively complete. I also made a list of things I could do if I put in the time. I was determined to finish the tasks to the best of my ability in order to get the highest mark possible.
result: Despite the limited time, due to other assessments for other units I had to complete also, I managed to complete most of the tasks to a high quality. This would not have been possible had I not used the resources available and had a sense of urgency.

situation: Towards the beginning of creating our individual Rude Goldberg Machine components, I needed to think of how I can create my components to the best ability. This required assessing the uniqueness, reliability and risk associated with each action of my RGM and relating back to the RGM goal and theme.
task_action: I had focused on vigorous testing and evaluation of designs and prototypes of each of my actions. Along with this, I recorded data of testing the components, improving upon their reliability of the RGM actions after each week. I also would analyse the successes and failures of the actions and creatively find solutions to the designs and test them. Regarding the RGM’s theme and our main goal of throwing a plastic bottle into a bin, I communicated the idea of integrating ‘repurpose, reuse, recycle’ to the team to go along with the main theme of recycling.
result: The testing results were very clear and concise to communicate my RGM test data to my team which helped create better presentations for all team members. It was easy to see the creative changes in design as the week’s progressed, with the reliability of tests increasing because of this. I found the most beneficial process was to understand the failures in design and finding ways to manage that. Communicating different ideas was possible as we could communicate using our whatsapp group chat to brainstorm and solve any issues that arose. PERSONAL FEELING/REFLECTION: As the group and I would solve issues with our individual RGM components, it would be very fulfilling to help others and work as a team to eventually come up with a finished project. LEARNING: Reflecting upon how we went about our component design, prototype, and creation stages, I feel that we could have been more time efficient as sometimes the group had issues with finishing the presentation slides a bit late in the week which from personal experience, would build pressure to the presenter for the week and make it a less effective and stressful situation. Although, communicating with setting time-constraints for each of our final RGM component videos, we will have ample time to edit our video and have more time to focus on the big week 13 presentation.

situation: During the HSC, i had three of my tests at the start of the second week providing me with limited studying time between each test.
task_action: Due to the limited timeframe, I assessed my previous marks and grades for the subjects and prioritised the order in which I should study the subjects based on my confidence and knowledge within each subject. Before the intensive week of testing, I had a free week, allowing me to allocate my study time over 7 days. I found legal studies to be the most difficult of the three subjects, followed by Visual Arts and Maths. I allocated most of the time towards legal studies, as my ranking was at the bottom of the class.
result: After studying intensely for Legal Studies, I found the test incredibly easy and achieved first in the class. Furthermore, as I was more confident in my other subjects, I still obtained a great mark, improving my overall results by focusing on my weaker subjects.

situation: In the ENGG1050 week four workshop, I was required to present my group’s problem definition to my tutor group.
task_action: Using my group’s Miro board as a written and visual aid, I explained our client scenario, spoke about some of our metrics for measuring success and failure, and detailed the different constraints which pertain to our project. I also gave a brief run-through of the incomplete draft chain of events our group had devised so far.
result: The result was an approximately 5 minute presentation delivering a summary of our problem definition and draft conceptual design to my tutor and peers.

situation: At work, I was tasked with distributing the bread orders. Unfortunately, the previous employee responsible for the bread orders left behind a convoluted list that was difficult to follow. This resulted in me having to find a more digestible way for myself and my coworkers to follow the list.
task_action: I studied the list in order to pinpoint the relevant information and customer details. Once acquired, I brainstormed different templates to help display and communicate the information in a more organised manner. This was best done by focusing on certain key parameters; such as alphabetical order, frequencies of orders, and priority.
result: The result was the creation of a formulated list of customer details (written by hand) that my coworkers ultimately found more comprehensible than the original, which allowed us to be more efficient as a team.

situation: I needed to devise a way of optimizing my time spent at university and at home towards my study on a budget. I have a Microsoft Surface Studio 2 desktop computer at home but when I was away from my desk I used to spend time on my phone trying to look at course work but couldn't read files properly on a small device. Sometimes when I was feeling tired and working straight off my bed I would end up listening to music on my phone without studying because I wasn't feeling like working behind my desk. I also needed a bigger device to communicate with Lecturers/Tutors in my course.
task_action: Undergoing a brainstorming session I devised several variable options. 1. To purchase a Microsoft Laptop studio or 2. To purchase a Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 4
result: The result was I Purchased a Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 4 and was able to utilize my time more efficiently at a cost of around $3000.

situation: * Recently, I went Scuba Diving as a type 1 diabetic. This was not my first time diving with diabetes, and at the beginning of the dive I gave a small presentation about this. I talked about what it meant to dive as a diabetic, including the potential risks and what I would need from people in case a situation arises. However, during the dive a complication arose due to my diabetes. The group I was diving with felt confused and unprepared, they were unsure of what they should do. This made me realise something, that I didn’t do an adequate job informing people of their role to play in case of an emergency. I needed to prepare and script a better presentation, to explain my diabetes to my dive partners.
task_action: * A close friend of mine is one of the best cave divers in the world. He put me in touch with one of his students, another type 1 diabetic. We sat on a phone call for about 4 hours, brainstorming all of the potential problems I could have underwater due to my diabetes and what those problems would mean for me, for the people I’m diving with, and how those problems would be managed or mitigated. Once we came up with that list, we worked out which of those problems I could manage on my own, and which of those problems required help from other people. From there, we created clear and concise explanations, including props and images, to explain only the problems that would require help from other people.
result: * We came up with a new presentation, one which did a much better job of preparing people. We did this by explaining the condition, what it means for me as a diver, the important hand symbol for diving with diabetes and what it means for a dive, the potential things I need from people, and stressing that certain problems just need time for me to work through them on my own, and that if I require assistance I will signal people for it. Using this method, I was able to create a much more effective presentation. I tried this out recently and did a mock simulation of a diabetes problem underwater, and no one from the diving group was confused or felt unequipped to handle this situation. This presentation was a success.

situation: The unit ENGG1050 is a fully online unit and it was my first time , I was studying a full unit online. So, it seemed difficult to me to communicate with my teammates online. Also, me and my teammates were confused in choosing software for presentations.
task_action: In our first session of class, I found that all of my teammates were friendly and we decided to make a whatsapp group for communication. Then one of my teammate shared a google document , this document purpose was to pick a common time for online team meetings , we all coloured timings red in which we were busy. At last for presentations, we consulted our tutor to decided which software is best.
result: As a result, we found a common time at which all were free for online meetings and our tutor referred us miro software and it's really best for making presentations and for communication.

situation: ENG1000 skill 1 Arduino final submission required the whole class to replicate a 4-bit binary adder. The adder needed to add numbers based on 2 seperate binary inputs and then displayed on an LCD screen. This task involved a high amount of advanced coding/circuit-building skills that were beyond the normal task level. These components and skills required appropriate prioritisation and focus so that the product could be presented in time.
task_action: Prioritisation is essential in project-based assessments because it directs an individual's effort to what is most needed and important. A great guideline to structure the priorities in our project was the marking guideline. The markers would allocate to us different marks depending on what part of the project we finished. The plan was to focus primarily on the highest-paying marks first and then the seperate lower marks. A huge prioritisation in this process involved learning the binary system and its code. The focus would be directed on how to make a system code that would read the binary and then add/display it on LCD and LED lights. Because coding is a complex subject, I prioritised my focus on researching and developing code to suit the binary.
result: Prioritising the binary code allowed me to create the foundational adder system that was needed for the project. Understanding the code allowed an extended time to work on additional marks of the project (e.g. the circuit, the LED displays).

situation: Throughout the now 11 weeks of the ongoing RGM project my team and I had developed and implemented a communication structure that was effective and worked well for everyone in the team. The structure has aided myself and my team in delivering information of what we must get done each week, which ongoingly helped us to succeed in completing the Rube Goldberg Machine project of a coffee machine.
task_action: From start of the entirety of the team project. My teams and I began discussing how and what communication platform the team would be using as the main method of communication for the throughout the completion of the RGM project. I had discussed with my fellow group members what common communication we used in common, that we could then use throughout the RGM project as our main tool/method of communication. We discussed options such as Zoom and Discord. We finally determined to use discord for our communication platform. Discord provided many advantages over zoom such as having a messaging feature that allowed to scroll back in time to view older tasks and information shared, whereas zoom only has a chat function within meetings that member must connect to, to chat. Discord allowed communication between myself and other team members throughout the 11 weeks and was not restricted to having everyone available at one time. Additionally, discord also had a voice chat feature which allowed my team to have meetings to discuss the project. The utilization of Discord was an initial step in establishing a good communication structure. With Discord, ideas and weekly briefs of tasks outlines could be discussed and completed, and distribution of tasks and roles was done so using discord. From week 1-2 my team and I had also determined what days and times we were all available for weekly meetings, which we decided upon Mondays as the ideal meeting time, and later this date changed to Thursday due to the busy schedules of individual members. This was another element that formed the communication structure for me throughout the entirety of the RGM project.
result: Having established an effective communication structure early on in weeks 1-2 allowed quick messages and information to be shared between all members throughout the 11 weeks so far. It enabled the sending and delivery of ideas from the initial aim of our RGM to the preliminary to conceptual then later detailed design and final preparation and combination of individual RGM elements.

situation: We needed to prepare an oral presentation to describe our Rube Goldberg Machine.
task_action: Undergoing a brainstorming and critical thinking session; we decided which three team members will be the most suitable for the presentation and we divided the contents of the presentation among the presenters. Presentation slides and a speech for each presenter was also made. A lot of practice presentations were done in front of the other teammates and each teammate gave their reviews which were used to refine the presentation. Each part of the machine was described inside the presentation along with accurate descriptions about testing, improvements, precautions, and our learnings so far. The introduction included a innovative sales pitch and our problem definition and the presentation ended with a conclusion that included our final thoughts. The contents of the presentation were selected based on importance and relevance.
result: The result was being able to produce a desirable presentation for our Rube Goldberg Machine which was relevant and discussed everything we wanted to about our RGM.

situation: In our software engineering course, we needed to brainstorm a design mechanism for unloading cans from a robot onto a shelving unit.
task_action: We organized a brainstorming session, forming a small working group with a clearly articulated problem statement. Using the gallery method of brainstorming, we generated several viable options. We then evaluated each suggested option and ranked them in order of importance based on parameters such as weight, complexity, and manufacturability.
result: We successfully selected a design solution from the six options generated during the brainstorming session. We divided the required tasks among team members for further development. REFLECTION: This experience significantly enhanced my communication skills in a software programming context. By articulating the problem clearly and using structured brainstorming techniques, we fostered an inclusive environment that encouraged diverse ideas. Evaluating and ranking the options required clear, concise communication and collaborative decision-making. This process not only improved my ability to convey technical information effectively but also underscored the importance of teamwork and structured communication in achieving successful project outcomes.

situation: We needed to verbally address the audience on a particular topic by presenting it and providing a cohesive argument or credible information.
task_action: Whilst practicing the presentation, focus was made on our eye contact skills, presented body language and emphasis on speaking clearly. Subsequently, we evaluated our performance on each of these skills in order to improve them, based on engagement, confidence and intonation.
result: The result was being able to practice and enhance each of these skills to provide a cohesive but engaging presentation to the audience, providing our credible evidence and confidence on the topic at hand.

situation: During the initial stages of team development, it was crucial for us to find an effective communication platform alongside developing a teamwork strategy and honing our communication skills. The teams were allocated members virtually, and the unit was designed that way.
task_action: Having talked in the first workshop meeting and learning a little about each other, we were able to break the ice. Following that, a communication platform needed to be sought via which we could comfortably articulate our thoughts and ideas. Although there were several viable options, Discord seemed to be the most compatible with the team members. Having this comfortable environment promoted communication, which is much needed for teamwork and team building. Another aspect of a functioning team is delegating tasks. This helped members identify their specified role and create a sense of responsibility to fulfill that requirement.
result: We were able to develop a functioning team where the members are fully aware of their roles and responsibilities. By contributing to our strengths, we were also able to cover each other's weaknesses and ultimately complete tasks with efficiency.

situation: During this semester I have had difficulty with appropriately managing my time. Specifically, in regards to balancing my part-time work with studying. At the beginning of the semester I was disorganised and working 35-40 hours a week. This caused me quite a bit of stress, which is reflected in my grades.
task_action: I re-evaluated my priorities and reflected on how I could realistically manage my time and resources (e.g. money). To do this I drew up a study plan which included a weekly checklist of the most important tasks for each of my five subjects. I also used a calendar board to visually display all due dates as well as when I should begin tasks, such as, assignments. To help me manage my resources I created a budget accounting for my major spending points, how I could reduce them and thereby how many hours I really need to work each week. Finally, I spoke to my manager to request less hours so I could focus on university.
result: The result has been effective to varying degrees of success. The visual calendar has successfully helped me submit assignments and prepare for tests. Additionally, the calendar helps me manage my time in all areas of my life, not just university related. However, less successfully is the amount of hours I work. My current place of work is very short on staff and as a result employees are pressured to work more hours. This is still an aspect of my time management that I am still attempting to improve.

situation: At the age of 17, I want to become a health provider, working in the NDIS industry or age care services. I had placed a goal in which I wanted to achieve but I understood the responsibilities it would require to take. At the time I was in yr11. I did my research and would often call up the NDIS and understand the process into becoming a registered provider. I had to prioritise a lot of my holidays and weekends understanding the process. Prioritization and focus is a skill that everyone should develop over there course of experience in the workplace. Prioritization is understanding the urgency of the matter and focusing on how to find a solution.
task_action: I had faced a lot of criticism from other Registered providers, they would often make it difficult for me with either providing me with incorrect information or false guidance. Having very limited qualifications, I had signed up to some online course which provide you with qualifications within short periods of time. I was focused in what I wanted to achieve and put a lot of dedication and hours doing research. I had to do a background check, and a few other checks to be deemed safe to work in the industry. I would stay up late at night prioritising family night doing research and gathering of my documents. With several restless nights I felt like things were getting nowhere. I was under qualified and the qualification in which I provided where not enough. I was focused and dedicated, I didn’t want the opportunity that I had go past me. I came up with a idea of which I would hire staff that which were qualified to work for me. It came to thought that I can ask for assistance from my uncles and aunties to provide there documents in which I can receive the registration approval. My dad has 11 siblings and all of which work. A few of my uncles work In the hospital and manage the ICU sector, a few of my aunties are teachers and there qualifications are suitable for the registration groups in which I applied for. The process took me over 1 month to gather all the documents. I had to priorities some of my time for my preliminary exam which I had in year 11 and that went on for around 2 and a half weeks. Prioritization and focus has become a part of a daily lives, which every decision we make requiring some form decision making. As I grown up, I understood that we have to priorities a lot of things in order to accomplish a dream and a goal. For me a dream was opening up a business, establishing a business wasn’t a easy process and it had required me to priorities a lot of my family time to become a provider. Although a lot of people still mention that I have university to look out for and I’m still young, then I should have the option of enjoying my time while I’m at it.
result: I believe to overcome challenges we must understand the objectives and focus our goals on what is more important. This is further reinforces by the “Eisenhower Matrix”. This form of prioritisation method is a task management method which I often use to maintain my day to day tasks. It is a form of planning method, you construct your duties into 4 categories and they go as followed, the tasks you do important and need to do first, the second section is for tasks which can be completed after or later on. When the important tasks are completed. Section 3 is tasks you require assistants with, so if someone can give you a hand in or knowledge to completing a task and lastly section 4 is deleting tasks which have been completed. This process helped me schedule my tasks into the 4 categories, this has enabled me to maximise my time spent on important tasks which are required to be completed leaving the non-urgent tasks to the end. At the end, after a restless 6 months going in and out of meetings, we had finally received the company registration. My family and I agreed that my dad will be the director in the business as he will be running for majority of the time while I complete my study. During the process I’ve learnt that the process of prioritisation and focusing is a fundamental part of our lives, taking on more responsibilities are we continue moving forward, we are required to often reflect on our progress and what we consider as our priorities. It enables us to create a great work balance between our work life and our family life, the use of “Eisenhower Matrix” allows me personally to reflect on my progress and make adjustments suitable to achieving that goal.

situation: We were tasked with completing a variety of basic coding and circuitry problems with an Arduino Uno board and its corresponding integrated development environment. Complementary to this, we were also asked to create a LinkedIn page and talk to our surrounding peers and to expand our network.
task_action: Everyone had access to a pdf file containing the problems and a supplementary guide on basic nomenclature of the key parts of the Arduino board and tools we were to use. Prior to completing the task we briefly set up a LinkedIn account and shared accounts with those around us. The tasks itself required us to: * _Use 4 LEDs to build a circuit which blinked one LED at a time consecutively_ * _Use 10 LEDs to build a circuit that counted through each one like numbers, counting first evenly and then oddly and then in prime order_ * _Use 4 LEDs to create a circuit that will count to 15 in binary_ We had a total of three hours to complete these tasks, with each task acting as a precedent for the knowledge required to complete the next. As there were varying degrees of knowledge with the Arduino board and for coding in general there was a lot of discourse amongst the class to try and work through the problems.
result: The result left everyone with a working circuit board tuned to solve its corresponding problem which was then marked off by the tutor and critiqued.

situation: When constructing our RGM events, we had some difficulty with creative designs, and communicating possible solutions for our individual events.
task_action: To overcome this problem, we first consulted with the rest of the team. In a team this should be the first step when you are presented with any problem. Referring to your team for help is useful for building greater teamwork, communication and problem solving skills. This method is not without its flaws, as creative solutions can be difficult to physically develop into a functional product. For certain problems it can also be very difficult to explain what the root cause of the problem is, even with the benefit of communication software like chatrooms and phone calls. Each team member is constructing and conducting tests individually in their own workspaces, and it can be very hard to offer solutions when each team member can't physically see the construction and determine the cause of the problem. After consolidating with the team, if the issue persists, it is also helpful to search resources online for similar problems or alternative methods for solutions.
result: The result from communicating solutions with team members is a stronger team. Sharing ideas with other people is a useful way to expand creative thinking skills, and develop more creative solutions to problems. The longer a team works together, they tend to develop similar ways of thinking and generating solutions, which helps in understanding the problem a team member is proposing. It then becomes easier to conceive a solution in a way that the team member will be able to understand and succeed upon. Online resources can help the team member find inspiration to potentially solve their problem or other collective issues the team may have. Online resources (e.g. videos) provide the ability to visualise a similar solution to your given problem. This will make it easier for the team member to solve their problem, developing their problem solving skills further.

situation: A task required us to derive an algorithm capable of determining the winner of a standard game of paper, scissor, rock, spock and lizard. Furthermore, the algorithm must be able to accomodate for an infinite array of possible hand gestures.
task_action: To start deriving the algorithm a pattern needed to be conceptualised. This was achieved by thinking of gestures as numerically values such as rock is 0 and paper is 1 and so forth. Then by finding the difference between the human and computer gesture, for example scissors vs paper as 2 - 1 = 1. To better understand the pattern, I organised the data into a table for analysis. In cases where the difference resulted in a negative value I adjusted it by adding the total number of gestures the user chose for that specific game. This process revealed a noticeable pattern: even numbers indicated a human loss while odd numbers indicated a human win. Consequently, the algorithm used modulo and conditional statements to determine the winner of the game.
result: The result was an algorithm capable of choosing the winner between human and computer gestures, even in cases involving large sets of gesture (to infinity).

situation: My schoolmates and I embarked on the challenge of orchestrating a flawlessly synchronised marching routine for our annual school competition. This endeavour undeniably called for intricate teamwork, effective communication and seamless coordination.
task_action: I facilitated a comprehensive group meeting to brainstorm ideas and allocate responsibilities, resulting in the formation of smaller teams among our 500-student batch, each led by its own leader. After in-depth strategy discussions, we swiftly transitioned into action. Recognising the need for rigorous practice, we immediately coordinated practice and additional sessions, maintaining this rigorous routine for two weeks leading up to the final competition.
result: Our dedication to teamwork and clear communication translated into a highly coordinated march, where every limb moved in perfect harmony with the guiding drumbeat. This relentless effort culminated in us proudly claiming the trophy for the Best March of the year.

situation: After individual introduction, our group consisted of very like minded individuals based off of our DISC and OCEAN results. This resulted in a limited amount of diversity affecting our creativity, understanding how to tackle an issue from multiple views & overall forming a strong link between each individual as we all had characteristics of seeking guidance rather than giving it.
task_action: As weeks passed, all members became more comfortable with sharing their opinions which gave me and two other members with more perseverance an opportunity to analyse which member needs guidance in different aspects of our Rube Goldberg Machine assignment. Pin pointing our weaknesses helped us lead a systematic approach towards who could pick up what would be dropped off by someone else. For example my strength as chairman and leading makes up for one of our more reserved members who claims to struggle in that department. in addition, to prevent unfair loads of responsibility based upon our strengths we take a moment within our extra meeting to work on each others flaws and address where a member could improve and how they could achieve development.
result: Out of the action taken, our team has been able to correlate & take advantage of our individuality & create strong links between each other. As levels of communication improved the groups creativity has had the opportunity to shine, further presenting the RGM to become a representation of each member, especially considering each problem faced became near inferior as the team worked in unison to provide an effective solution.

situation: Our group was given a project with multiple tasks (report, model and presentation) that have different due dates.
task_action: Evaluate the amount of time given for each task; evaluate the times where each group member is free or available to work on each task; prioritise each task based of importance and due dates; allocate time to complete task within schedule; have checkpoints throughout the given time to ensure progress of each task. Due to the limited time we had to construct our model as this could only be done in class, most of our in-class time was spent on the model while our time spent outside of class was used to work on the report and presentation. The report (what I was tasked to do) was divided into its sections which allowed me to create 'checkpoints' that I could use to track progress to see whether I was on schedule or behind schedule.
result: This allowed me to see how much time our group has to complete each task, ensure that I will have enough time to work on the project and be able to complete the project within the given time.

situation: We needed to present a presentation on the importance of cyber security in the modern world and each member has to speak for 5 minutes.

After that we divided the focus areas between 5 members of the group so that each member can speak for one minute. Since the topic is broad, each member has to make sure to mention only the main key points hence they don't cross the time limit for their part of the presentation. Furthermore, we also make sure that every member that speaks has some correlation about the topic which the previous speaker conveyed so that their is a smooth transition hence all the listeners can understand well.
result: The result was completing the presentation on time and each member playing a crucial part in presenting well.

situation: As a team , we encountered significant issues with managing our project timelines and resources. Tasks were frequently delayed, and resource allocation was often inefficient, leading to overworked team members and unmet deadlines. This situation was creating stress within the team and dissatisfaction among team members and our tutor.
task_action: Our task was to improve our time and resource management practices to ensure projects were completed on schedule and resources were utilized efficiently. The objective was to enhance team productivity, reduce stress, and improve tutor satisfaction.Subsequently, * Identified key pain points and areas for improvement * Provided ongoing support and addressed any issues that arose during the transition.
result: This experience underscored the importance of structured time and resource management practices in achieving project success. By implementing the right tools and processes, we were able to enhance productivity, meet tutor expectations, and create a more positive and efficient working environment.

situation: The aim was to build an aluminium toolbox with precision, assuring little material waste and early completion.
task_action: First, I thoroughly planned the project, drawing up a complete blueprint with exact measurements for each component. Despite my meticulous preparation, I made a mistake during the cutting process and cut one of the pieces too short. Recognising the error, I quickly stopped the procedure to analyse the situation. To fix the issue, I saw I needed to cut out a new piece to replace the one that was too short.I took quick action, measuring the right proportions to ensure no further errors, and carefully cutting out a fresh piece from the aluminium sheet. Throughout the procedure, I remained focused and precise, emphasising the significance of double-checking measures after learning from my error.
result: Despite the initial setback, I was able to replace the wrong piece with the newly cut one without any delay. Following that, the project went successfully, with the toolbox completed on time and by all design parameters. This experience taught me the value of attentiveness and attention to detail in precision crafting, which in turn improved my time and resource management skills.

situation: WE NEEDED TO CREATE A BINARY CALCULATOR USING AN ARDUINO CIRCUIT ,LEDS,BUTTONS, AND A LCD DISPLAY. EACH BUTTON SHOULD TURN ON ITS RELATIVE LED TO DISPLAY A NUMBER IN BINARY NOTATION , AN EXTRA BUTTON IS PRESSED TO STORE THE FIRST NUMBER, THEN AFTER ANOTHER NUMBER IS ENTERED PRESSING THE BUTTON ADDS THE NUMBERS THEN DISPLAYS THE SUM ON THE LCD DISPLAY AND IN BINARY NOTATION ON THE LEDS
task_action: TO SOLVE THE CALCULATOR PROBLEM, I APPROACHED IT FROM MULTIPLE ANGLES, BUT THE BEST SOLUTION WAS TO BREAK IT DOWN INTO MULTIPLE PARTS. THIS INVOLVED CREATING MANY SEPARATE CIRCUITS. TO KNOW WHAT CIRCUITS TO BUILD A BRAINSTORM WAS DRAWN UP SHOWING ALL THE SEPARATE FUNCTIONS THAT THE CALCULATOR HAD TO ACHIEVE.THEN THESE FUNCTIONS WERE ASSIGNED TO SMALLER CIRCUITS THAT COULD BE INTEGRATED INTO A LARGER SYSTEM. EXAMPLES OF THE SMALLER INDIVIDUAL CIRCUITS ARE AS FOLLOWS BUT LIMITED TO 4 BUTTONS WHICH TURN ON THEIR RESPECTIVE LEDS, BINARY TO DECIMAL CONVERTER AND SUM OF TWO NUMBER CIRCUITS. AT THE END OF THE CREATION OF THESE INDIVIDUAL CIRCUITS THEY ALL HAD TO BE COMBINED TO CREATE A FULLY FUNCTIONING BINARY CALCULATOR.
result: THE RESULT OF CREATING A CLEAR PLAN TO DESIGN THE CIRCUIT ALLOWED FOR AN EASY CREATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF CIRCUITS WITH RELATIVE EASE , ALLOWING FOR THE CREATION OF THE FULLY CREATED END PRODUCT WHICH MEETS ALL OF ITS SPECIFICATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS.

situation: Throughout week three and four, we discussed potential designs to use for our Rube Goldberg Machine and the quickest way to get a preliminary design.
task_action: During these two weeks, each member was given the task to research on designs for inspiration, which after they would produce their own design idea prior to the next scheduled meeting. Then as a group, we can evaluate and tweak the individual designs according to our theme and rubric.
result: As a result of this, it allowed us to produce a full preliminary design within a short time frame giving us ample time to modify if necessary. Managing our time efficiently, meant the meetings were more productive.

situation: The group needed to brainstorm preliminary designs of the Rube Goldberg Machine and evaluate the feasibility of those ideas as well as determine the scope of creativity they'd allow the group to achieve.
task_action: The group conducted a thorough review of several YouTube videos featuring preliminary design concepts. This exploration served as a foundation for our creative process, inspiring us to branch out and develop our own unique designs such as the flow/transportation of water. Through personal research, the members further uncovered creative ways of approaching the machine's design, enriching our design process.
result: Our efforts enabled us to express creativity while maintaining a clear and feasible vision for the machine. We've successfully blended inspiration from various sources with our personal research, ensuring that our ideas are both imaginative and achievable within our project's constraints.

situation: During week five our group brainstormed our conceptual design for the Rube Goldberg Machine (RGM) which would involve various modularized systems culminating in pressing the space bar on a laptop.
task_action: Using the problem definition from the previous group meeting, we identified the design constraints for our RGM machine: each member creates two unique events with each lasting a minimum 3 seconds, each event flows seamlessly to the next, materials are supplied using household items and the total system lasts a maximum 5 minutes. Next, we established the sequence of system in terms of member, who has initiating system and who finishes the system. Subsequently, we brainstormed various ideas and systems we could use for different events such as dominoes, pulley systems, ramps, balls/marbles, tubes, fans and so on. From there, we collectively brainstormed variations how each item/idea could be implemented in an event. Once all the suggested ideas were thoroughly assessed, each idea was ranked against different variations in terms of feasibility given time constraint, complexity, and uniqueness.
result: The result was collectively selecting 10 conceptual ideas from the list of 20 ideas brainstormed. Further, two mechanisms were given to each member depending on their assigned position within the RGM system to maximise a seamless transition between each event. This was done collectively after the team discussed and assessed each idea in various positions along the RGM machine.

situation: Upon starting ENGG1050 in week 1 there were immediately some challenges faced. Given the lengthy end of year holidays, my brain was not primed for the future weeks of academic studies ahead. This of course is only to be expected, but in addition to this, I have reflected on my last year results and know that they were not optimal; there is a bit of room for improvement and I need to be prepared this semester. The writing of this assessment task has made me realise that this ‘room for improvement’ is in fact a lack of time management and organisation.
task_action: In order to make a change I decided that I needed a system in place that would work with my weaknesses so that I could focus on the actual content of this unit, and produce my best work. In week 1 there is a lot of new important information about assignments and how the unit will be structured. Due dates are not something you should rely on your brain to remember, therefore I downloaded a calendar app and a to-do list app.
result: When used in conjunction with each other, I would be able to track important dates, plan ahead and manage my time a lot more wisely. This is a huge step up from last semester where I did not have a defined and much-needed system in place; I only had a simple to-do list that I did not stick to, therefore making it a lot harder to visually track and coordinate tasks, leading to a lot of disorganisation. This semester, this system has been working well for me as I have not repeated these same mistakes.

As a result, I successfully met the project requirements and received positive feedback on the clarity and precision of my drawings. This experience underscored the importance of critical thinking in engineering tasks, emphasizing the need to approach challenges methodically and continuously refine one's work to achieve optimal results.

Where multiple attempts at coding each section proved more valuable as I was able to critically analyse my task requirements and effectively create solutions the conditions and variables required with my RPS game.
result: The result of utilising critical thinking is formed through my ability to analyse each problem effectively and ultimately create in depth solutions that would prove my project successful and ready to be submitted. Effectively breaking down each step in order to progress with the creation of my game.

situation: Over the past 6 years I have worked professionally as a Diagnostic Radiographer across many public and private healthcare facilities. To this day I can still recollect my very first nightshift, and the experiences that I had learnt from it. Working in the Townsville University Hospital this night, I was the sole radiographer providing all the Medical Imagining services across both Xray and CT for the entire hospital. It was a busy night and at some point, I received two phone calls within seconds of each other, one was theatre stating they had an anesthetised patient on the table and needed x-rays, and the other was a MET (Medical emergency team) Call attending a patient with acute shortness of breath that needed me also. As I was leaving the workstation to change into my theatre attire, there was an announcement made through the emergency PA system “Paediatric Rapid Response to RESUS”.
task_action: I immediately called the second on-call Radiographer, explained what was happening and asked them come in. I got changed into scrubs, informed ED and the MET call team that I had to attend theatre urgently and that another radiographer would be there shortly. Once I had finished screening (taking x-rays) for the theatre case, I returned to the medical imaging department, sent the on-call radiographer home and continued the rest of the shift. Although I applied good critical thinking to able to overcome this sudden spike in the workload, I wanted to make a change, so that something like this would not happen again, to myself or my colleagues. So, I approached my team leader with my concerns about the increased workload and the pressure it has on the sole nightshift radiographer, especially the less experienced graduates (as I was). I also addressed the issue, with statistics I had gathered, in staff meetings and with the deputy director at the time advocating for increased support for the nightshift radiographer and especially for graduates undertaking nightshift for the first time.
result: At the Townsville University Hospital, I have since been the last radiographer to ever (since 2019) work their first nightshift alone. As part of my advocating for a change and the support of my colleagues, the first initial nightshift for any new staff member is rostered with a ‘buddy’, another experienced radiographer to help guide them through the afterhours procedures and processes. Although I did also advocate for a second radiographer to be rostered to nightshift indefinitely due to the increased workload, I cannot claim that I was reason that they decided to do so. COVID-19 and the increased workload that came with it was, but I supported this and undertook additional nightshifts to help the nightshift radiographer.

situation: We as a group were tasked to form an effective team to create a Rube Goldberg Machine that performs a simple task.
task_action: Our group worked effectively and efficiently through forming and following roles within the team that rotated weekly. From the beginning we were tasked to take a DISC and OCEAN survey which produced results which show our own individual attributes, such as who was more of a leader and who was more of a supporter; who was more of a creative person or rather more logistic. With these results we were able to devise a rotation of roles throughout the weeks, these roles being; The "Chair Person" - Who would take control of the meetings that week and would be in charge of keeping everyone on track, updated and on topic throughout meetings. The "Minute Taker" - Takes notes and minutes of each pre-workshop and workshop meetings, and is also in charge of making the agenda for the upcoming week. Also responsible for writing but not creating the weeks reflection as the teams reflection is a group task, but the minute taker is in charge of typing out and emailing both the minutes and the reflection to the tutor. The "Presenter" - Creates and presents the presentation based on the topic of that week.
result: By creating these roles and responsibilities, each person in the team was able to contribute effectively and evenly throughout the weeks as each person had a chance to have their say. We as a team were able to perform our tasks mostly on time and have all contributed each our own thoughts and ideas effectively.

situation: For our group project in COMP1300, we were asked to prepare a presentation on Data Breaches. task_action: I also conducted a meeting to discuss communication and teamwork issues; I also started a WhatsApp group for real-time discussions and used Google Docs for collaborative work. result: Although our strategies resulted in improved communication and teamwork, it was a process. We got the presentation done early, and we scored high, and we got to work together on a few more projects.

situation: Making a toolbox, with limited resources and minimal time.

result: The result was being able to build our toolboxes on time and make minimal to no mistakes when cutting and measuring our toolbox pieces, leaving the worry for limited resources.

They were then drawn on paper in several formats such as two point perspective and Multiview. This establishes that critical thinking was needed to determine these variables.
result: The result or outcome was not only the successful illustration of the shapes but a well recognised use of critical thinking.

situation: We had to schedule and distribute individual time across the week to get ready for our weekly presentation and devise/create concepts, plans and materials for our RGM project.
task_action: It was a responsibility that all team members allocated time each week to work on projects and presentations. Through team meetings, discussions, zoom meetings and phone calls we were able to commenced by evaluating the available week's timeframe, breaking down tasks for both the presentation and RGM project. A team meeting was orchestrated to define objectives and generate ideas collaboratively. A well-balanced schedule was crafted, accounting for presentation groundwork and project conceptualisation. We come up with the presentational design where each week the rotation of roles will be turned so that every week a different team member was presenting. How we kept the time management going is the we used online talking platforms like zoom, WhatsApp and phone calls to keep track of everyone availability and keep everyone updated on the upcoming meetings and allocated times. We even shared calendars so that we can know exactly we will be coming to the meeting on that certain weeks. We also had to make time throughout the week to discuss how we going to come up with our certain RGM project and how we going to enable it to work and the team encouraged a dynamic brainstorming environment where every team member felt empowered to contribute their ideas without reservation. As ideas flowed, the individual adeptly guided the discussions, helping the team to identify the most promising concepts. These concepts were then subjected to a rigorous evaluation process, assessing factors such as feasibility, innovation, and alignment with project goals. Through depth discussions and analysing how we are going to use materials to build certain aspects of our machine we managing resource management by writing down the cost of each product and also who is going o transport which product on the day of creation.
result: The combined efforts of these actions culminated in a cohesive and strategic approach to both the presentation and the RGM project. This approach not only facilitated the successful completion of immediate tasks but also laid the groundwork for enduring teamwork and effective project execution. Thanks to our well-structured approach and effective time allocation, we delivered a polished and engaging presentation that effectively conveyed our ideas. Our presentation was well-received by our peers and garnered valuable feedback. For the RGM project, our collaborative brainstorming led to a diverse range of innovative ideas. Through careful evaluation and refinement, we narrowed down our concepts to a few strong directions. The outcome was a set of well-defined plans and design materials that laid a solid foundation for the next phases of the project. By strategically managing time, promoting collaboration, and balancing tasks, we achieved a successful presentation and set our RGM project on a promising trajectory. This experience underscored the importance of effective planning and teamwork in achieving project goals.

situation: In _Software Design Logic_, we were tasked to complete a multitude of activities before signing off for the day.
