For example, user-made functions in a _Rock, Paper, Scissors_ C program were to be edited and successfully integrated to make the game work. This was then presented to a tutor.
task_action: Up until this point, I had no further understanding of what C was, what modularity was or how to achieve reusability. This was when the skill: clear communication and solid teamwork, was being developed. A good friend of mine was in the same ENGG1000 unit as I was, and I was able to ask them deliberate questions that would help extend my understanding of C and coding in general. They helped me understand how to create user-made functions and how to successfully utilise them.
result: Their assistance and guidance has helped me develop a better understand about code and how it can be utilised. They have helped me complete the tasks that we were assigned to do. (The code provided to us was a _Rock, Paper, Scissors_ program that required the programmer to understand how to use its user-made functions and test them using code. Their teachings has helped me complete them).

situation: Firstly, I'd like to note that I currently work as a steelfixer in the construction industry to make a living, even though my actual field of study is software engineering. On one particular occasion, my co-workers and I were tasked with setting up steel protection for a clean water supply pipe in a major suburb in Sydney.
task_action: We began by reviewing engineer plan. This entailed ensuring all measurements, such as the concrete's height and width, all fundamental aspects of steelfixing were clarified and comprehended. With all the necessary information in hand, my co-workers and I distributed roles: deciding who would cut the steel, who would handle measurements, and who would be responsible for lifting and transporting the bars.
result: Despite the initial plan not being entirely fit to real world conditions, our team proficiently and independently addressed the problem, successfully repairing the clean water supply pipe. After our intervention, we confidently handed over the restored system to the lead engineer for final evaluation.

situation: In a programming course focused on honing critical thinking skills, the assignment was to individually create a C language code for a rock-paper-scissors game. The task required not only technical proficiency but also critical analysis and problem-solving abilities to develop an efficient and logically sound solution.
task_action: To approach this task with critical thinking, I began by thoroughly understanding the game's rules and requirements, breaking them down into logical components. I critically analyzed the problem, identifying potential challenges and areas where critical decision-making would be essential. Next, I formulated a plan to implement the game, considering factors such as user input validation, random selection of the computer's choice, and determining the winner based on the chosen options. This involved breaking down the problem into smaller, more manageable tasks and considering multiple potential solutions for each. Throughout the coding process, I continuously applied critical thinking skills to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of my code. I considered factors such as code readability, efficiency, and scalability, making informed decisions to optimize the code structure and improve its overall quality. When encountering challenges or ambiguities during implementation, I engaged in critical problem-solving, carefully analyzing the problem from different angles and considering alternative approaches. This involved debugging and troubleshooting, as well as seeking input from peers or resources to gain new insights and perspectives.
result: By applying critical thinking skills throughout the development process, I successfully created a functional and well-structured C language code for the rock-paper-scissors game. The implemented solution effectively handled user input validation, generated random choices for the computer, and accurately determined the winner based on the game's rules. Moreover, the experience of developing the code enhanced my critical thinking abilities, particularly in the areas of problem-solving, decision-making, and analytical reasoning. It underscored the importance of approaching programming challenges with a critical mindset, systematically analyzing problems, considering alternative solutions, and continuously evaluating and improving the code. Overall, the assignment served as a valuable exercise in integrating technical proficiency with critical thinking skills in software development

situation: We needed to brainstorm a conceptual and a preliminary design for our Rube Goldberg Machine.

situation: We faced a problem where our software's response time was slow, resulting in poor user experience and customer satisfaction.
task_action: We identified the root cause of the problem and realized that the codebase had several performance issues. To address this, we formed a small working group and set the task of optimizing the codebase for better performance. We conducted a thorough code review and identified the code segments responsible for the slow response time. We then implemented several optimization techniques, such as refactoring, caching, and code parallelization, to improve the performance.
result: As a result of our actions, the software's response time was reduced by more than 50%, resulting in significant improvements in user experience and customer satisfaction. Additionally, the software's stability improved, and we received positive feedback from our stakeholders. Our efforts also reduced server load and operational costs, resulting in a more cost-effective solution for our organization.

situation: Through the RGM process we had to take our previously established designs and apply critical thinking and logical analysis to construct a cohesive and reliable RGM to explore our engineering and problem-solving skills
task_action: Interpreting complex designs in a group session; organising a meeting time for everyone to bring their designs to the group to establish any technical issue and to gain insight on how others use critical thinking and problem solving to take what is on paper into something physically that works as intended. We engaged the team through a round-robin brainstorming method to allow everyone to get a chance to voice their opinion, evaluating each suggestion with a majority vote/discussion to determine the best solution.
result: This allowed an individual in the group to receive critical feedback on their initial designs from a group's perspective which assisted in the individual approach when interpreting and analysing their designs. This time saved on the construction process as the designs have been adjusted to work more efficiently and reliable, also allowing us to develop the skills of problem-solving and critical thinking to bring into our next project

It ultimatley allowed me to develop a solution to the problem by creating a mathematical algorithm, then converting it into code for the game after this.

situation: I had to create a toolbox, using either aluminium or steel. I chose to use aluminium.
task_action: In this unit, we had to use a mixture of small and large, heavy-duty tools, which meant we had to know what each tool was used for, how they function and what materials can be used when using those tools. By having class discussions before entering the machining area, we were able to discuss the differences between machines and their functionality, along with safety precautions, and things we needed to do to keep ourselves, our peers, and our surroundings safe, such as tying hair back, tucking lose clothes, and wearing safety glasses.
result: The result was being able to learn and use these heavy machines to complete our project, in a safe and sensible manner. We were also able to help those who were stuck on using machines, such as how to use a deburrer to make our cut edges smooth.

result: While initially somewhat haphazard over the first few weeks, our oral presentation became better as we became more used to the task, and we had better understanding of the requirements for both the oral presentation and supporting visual presentation.

situation: In Year 12 our engineering studies class had an assignment to create a rocket and reach high altitudes by modifying and innovating the design of the rocket.
task_action: The rocket design started with a 2-litre bottle without any modifications, resulting in a height of 15 meters. After receiving a baseline height, we attached a nose cone to the top of the rocket. We used a styrofoam dome, which reduced the height to 13.1 meters. So, we innovated the design to the conical top half of a Coke bottle, which enhanced the height to 17.7 meters. Following this, we constructed our first set of rocket fins, consisting of four elliptical wooden fins, which achieved a height of 9.7 meters but proved excessively heavy. We then redesigned the fins innovating it by using corflute material and changing the amount of fins to three elliptical fins, resulting in an improved trajectory of 16.4 meters. Further innovation led to a redesign of the fin shape into a trapezoidal fin, which allowed for rocket to reach a height of 20.3 meters, showing successful innovation. Our final innovation involved the addition of an epoxy resin cone to the top which replaced the Coke bottle conical top, this enhanced the tip and provided a counterweight, causing the best result of 27.5 meters.
result: The results showed how the innovation process is used to improve the rocket altitude. this was proven successful with the final rocket launch being 27.5m

situation: During our Software Design Logic workshops, we faced a series of coding challenges that required not only implementing software but also understanding the underlying logic. The pinnacle of these workshops was a final project where we had to create various versions of the game Rock-Paper-Scissors, including extended versions like Rock-Paper-Lizard-Spock and even more complex ones with 7, 9, and 11 gestures.
task_action: Our task was to develop algorithms and implement code for these game variants. We started by creating flowcharts to visualise the algorithms before diving into the coding phase. This involved critical thinking to determine the optimal structure and logic for each game variant. We had to thoroughly analyse the rules and interactions between gestures, ensuring our logic was robust and adaptable for more complex variants. Additionally, we performed unit tests to validate the correctness of our implementations.
result: Through precise planning and critical analysis, we successfully developed and implemented the code for all required game variants. Our flowcharts proved to be invaluable in organising our thoughts and providing a clear path for coding. The unit tests confirmed the reliability of our algorithms, ensuring that each game variant operated correctly. This process not only helped us complete the project successfully but also honed our critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

situation: We recently encountered a customer who operated a manufacturing facility experiencing issues with its wastewater treatment system. The plant had an outdated and underperforming wastewater treatment system. This was causing regulatory and environmental problems due to its ineffective treatment capabilities.
task_action: Our challenge was to design and implement a more sustainable wastewater treatment system to meet regulatory requirements and minimize the company’s footprint. We assembled a diverse team of water management, chemical processing, and environmental engineering experts to tackle this complex problem. First, we conducted a comprehensive review of the existing business wastewater treatment system to identify key areas that must be addressed. Then we examined innovative technology and best practices in the wastewater treatment industry. We focused on methods that require minimal energy, chemicals, and waste. Based on our assessments, we recommended a multi-pronged approach that included investing in the company’s treatment plants to incorporate state-of-the-art equipment such as membrane bioreactors and advanced oxidation systems. The company was also recommended to implement recycling programs. Other process improvements were generated to enhance resource recovery and reduce waste. In the implementation stage, we worked closely with the company’s technical staff to ensure the proper setup and operation of the new systems and processes. Training and support were provided to help the staff adapt to the changes and to improve the systems’ performance over time. All these measures led to a significant reduction in the company’s waste footprint and the diversion of substantial amounts of recyclable materials
result: Our sustainable wastewater treatment solution significantly benefits to both the company and the environment. The company saved water, electricity and chemicals, leading to increased production efficiency and lower operating costs. Furthermore, the new treatment plant enabled a considerable reduction of pollutants discharged into nature which helped preserve the nearby natural ecosystems and fulfilled legal regulations. In summary, our solution addressed pressing environmental concerns and contributed to corporate sustainability. This real-life example demonstrated to the students how engineering can work towards creating a better society and environment.

situation: In my ENGG2050 unit, one of the very first tasks we had to accomplish was creating a conceptual solution for an Internet of Things (IoT) Tea Maker. When this was first explained to us, I felt very lost, as I hadn’t done any sort of design similar to this. I felt even more overwhelmed when we were told that this design was going to be required in order for us to complete another assessment later in the semester (A6 Video Presentation). I felt as though I was going to fail the unit before it had even started. However, this is where my chosen soft skill came into play. My skills in “creating new solution concepts” were still very limited as I had only completed two semesters so far and didn’t have too much experience in applying myself to create real world solutions. So, during the semester I had to figure out a way to use and further hone my skills in creating new solutions. Doing this was going to be vital, not only for my final grade but also in order for me not to feel too overwhelmed by what was expected of me.
task_action: The task presented to me at the start of my 3rd semester at university in my ENGG2050 unit was to create a conceptual solution for an Internet of Things (IoT) Tea Maker. I had to not only meet the different criterias given to us but also ensure that if my solution was to be implemented in the real world, it would work. Whilst I didn’t have to delve into the actual physical implementation of the Tea Maker (i.e. the electrical, mechanical and other components), I had to create a solution that if given to an actual manufacturer or company, they would be able to implement the solution. This meant that I had to consider every possibility of what could go wrong and describe the details of the IoT Tea Maker in as much detail as I could. I was able to complete this through the help of my soft skill and the weekly SGTAs. The very first step that I took was to ask questions in the public discussion forum on iLearn. As this task was supposed to replicate a real world scenario as accurately as possible, we were tasked with asking questions on the discussion forum, where the unit convenor would reply from the perspective of a customer. From this we were expected to extract relevant information to identify the needs of the customer. I made sure to ask even the briefest questions I had. Additionally, not only were we given responses to our own questions, but also the questions that other people asked and their responses. From the discussion forum, I copied every question/answer into a document and underneath jotted down a couple of sentences on how I would be able to meet the customer’s requirement for that dot point. Here I was able to use my soft skill (creating new solution concepts) from my previous experiences of creating software solutions in other units. From experience, I knew that the very first step in creating a solution was to identify the requirements. I knew that these requirements were going to form the basis for the more detailed functions that I was going to have to describe. By calling on my soft skill, I was able to reduce the initial feeling of overwhelmingness I felt when the task was given to us. The next action I took was discussing and brainstorming possible designs in a group. Despite having previous experience in working in groups, I was still a bit nervous when we had to discuss our ideas with people who we had just met. However, this discussion was greatly beneficial as the group discussion highlighted different ideas and solutions for the tea maker that I had not considered. As we all came from different disciplines, the group discussion was very effective and we were able to gain insight from different perspectives. This action helped me realise the important role that group discussions play when creating a new solution. I was able to improve my chosen soft skill through this. Another action that I took was to consider the worst case scenario for certain aspects of the tea maker. For each individual function that I had described for my tea maker, I decided to question it and ask myself what would happen in the worst case (e.g. One of the functions was to store milk and my worst case scenario question was, what would happen if someone stored another liquid that could result in a possible accident?). This form of testing and evaluating my solution enabled me to see how I would be able to improve my solution. Moreover it taught me what scenarios to consider for the next time when I have to create a solution. This action helped me improve my “creating a solution” skill as I was able to learn how to reflect, question and improve my ideas.
result: My efforts were intended for me to use and improve my skills in creating a solution by creating a solution for my ENGG2050 IoT Tea Maker. Despite having limited experience with this soft skill and my discipline being Software Engineering (in which everything is very binary i.e. yes/no, 1/0) I was able to create a solution that could hypothetically be given to a manufacturer as an initial design. Furthermore, because of the actions that I implemented, I was able to improve my skills in creating a solution. Such a skill is going to be needed in future units and also my career. Knowing how to effectively create a solution concept is the basis of implementing successful engineering solutions. By improving my skills and completing my IoT Tea Maker solution to the best of my ability, I was content in my work and the initial daunting feeling I had when coming into this unit was gone.
